sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using inverse matrices
message_1:
Solve the following system of linear equations using inverse matrices:
 
x + y + z = 6

2x - y + 4z = 4

3x + 2y - z = 2

Find the values of x, y, and z using inverse matrices.
message_2:
To solve the system of linear equations using inverse matrices, we first need to write the given system in matrix form AX = B, where A is the matrix of coefficients, X is the column matrix of variables (x, y, z), and B is the column matrix of constants.

A = | 1  1  1 |
    | 2 -1  4 |
    | 3  2 -1 |

X = | x |
    | y |
    | z |

B = | 6 |
    | 4 |
    | 2 |

Now, we need to find the inverse of matrix A (A^(-1)). To do this, we first find the determinant of A.

det(A) = 1(-1(-1) - 4(2)) - 1(2(-1) - 4(3)) + 1(2(2) - 3(-1))
       = 1(1 + 8) - 1(-2 - 12) + 1(4 + 3)
       = 1(9) + 1(14) + 1(7)
       = 9 + 14 + 7
       = 30

Since the determinant is non-zero, the inverse of A exists. Now, we find the adjoint of A and then divide each element by the determinant to get A^(-1).

adj(A) = | (-1(-1) - 4(2))  -(2(-1) - 4(3))   (2(2) - 3(-1)) |
         | -(1(-1) - 4(2))   (1(-1) - 1(3))  -(1(2) - 2(-1)) |
         |  (1(2) - 1(2))   -(1(2) - 2(3))    (1(1) - 1(-1)) |

adj(A) = | -7  10   7 |
         |  7  -4  -3 |
         |  0   4   2 |

Now, we find A^(-1) by dividing each element of adj(A) by det(A).

A^(-1) = 1/det(A) * adj(A)

A^(-1) = 1/30 * | -7  10   7 |
                |  7  -4  -3 |
                |  0   4   2 |

A^(-1) = | -7/30  10/30  7/30 |
         |  7/30  -4/30 -3/30 |
         |   0     4/30  2/30 |

Now, we can find the values of x, y, and z by multiplying A^(-1) with B.

X = A^(-1) * B

X = | -7/30  10/30  7/30 |  | 6 |
    |  7/30  -4/30 -3/30 |  | 4 |
    |   0     4/30  2/30 |  | 2 |

X = | (-7/30)(6) + (10/30)(4) + (7/30)(2) |
    | (7/30)(6) + (-4/30)(4) + (-3/30)(2) |
    | (0)(6) + (4/30)(4) + (2/30)(2)      |

X = | 2 |
    | 1 |
    | 3 |

So, the values of x, y, and z are:

x = 2
y = 1
z = 3
